utterances: We'll turn now to a man who studied supermax units up close.
Walter Dickey ran the prison system in Wisconsin as that state's secretary of corrections.
He's now a law professor at the University of Wisconsin.
I asked him how a seemingly petty criminal could get locked up in a supermax unit for years at a time.
Well, there are a lot of different ways someone like that could end up in a supermax prison.
One is false or inaccurate factual information that's used as the basis for the transfer there.
I think that's probably as often the case as not.
Secondly, given the crowding that's going on in an awful lot of prison systems, there's enormous pressure to fill beds.
And if there's empty beds in a supermax institution, the pressure to, in a sense, overclassify people and indicate that they need a greater level of security than they may is enormous.

I think a third way is a prisoner might be mentally ill, might be difficult to manage in some other way, and in a sense, supermaxes can become dumping grounds for prisoners that staff and wardens don't want to deal with in regular prisons.
Well, how does one get out, provided that the prisoner is, you know, not misbehaving and just wants to get into general population?

Well, I think this is a vital part of prison administration, particularly in supermax institutions, that there be methods by which a person can demonstrate their ability or capacity to function in the general population like other prisoners because if they don't have that kind of an opportunity, then they and the prison administrators can never have confidence that they should be put in other sorts of settings.
The whole notion of the supermax was that it was supposed to make the rest of the prison population safer.
Is there any evidence of that?
Certainly anecdotally.
I think if you ask prison wardens, they'll say their places are calmed down and safer.
Whether or not there have been studies of that that have actually examined the effect on prison systems is dubious.
I don't know of any such studies.

And I would say this is what I think is a more educated guess than something I could prove, that an awful lot of the impetus for the building of the supermax prisons was political because it really presents a political picture of tough on crime and all that sort of stuff.
You were the Wisconsin state secretary of corrections in the mid-1980s, and that was around the time that the crack cocaine epidemic swept the country.
The prevailing thinking very much began to be lock them up, if not throw away the key, lose it for a good long while.
Are we starting to move away from that attitude?
I think so, and I think we can see the signs of our backing off that in many different places.

One is I think there've been some modifications in the sentencing system, certainly in the federal system, and I think we've also seen it in the states, that at least attempt to diminish the duration of confinement, as well as the amount of confinement.
These people do come back into society.

So, the idea that they can be salted away or something like that forever is ridiculous, and I think a recognition that they're coming back has certainly woken many leaders up to the idea that we need to do a better job of both preparing them for that return and also for supporting them and supervising them when they do return.
Walter Dickey is a former Wisconsin state secretary of corrections.
He joined us from the studios of Wisconsin Public Radio in Madison.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.

There's no clear plan for what to do with many thousands of family members of ISIS fighters who are in Syria, but many of them have a plan or at least an aspiration to return to the caliphate.
NPR's Jane Arraf recently visited a vast detention camp in northeastern Syria.
She met the women and their children, who are scraping for what they need to live in vastly overcrowded conditions.
Jane, thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you, Scott.
Please help us understand what you saw.
Do we call it a refugee camp, internment or prison camp?
You know, it's hard to know what to call it because most people have never seen anything like it before.
It's a combination refugee camp for people from outside Syria displaced by the fighting, Iraqis who were displaced.
It's a combination camp for people who are hiding out from the Syrian regime, but most of all, it's a detention camp - it's supposed to be a detention camp - for the families of ISIS fighters.
And there are 73,000 people in this camp now.
It's hugely overcrowded, not enough food, not enough anything.
And 65 percent of these people are children.
So essentially when the territorial caliphate of ISIS was defeated, this is the spiritual caliphate that was left, these ISIS families who had lived under the Islamic State for five years.
It sounds like from your reporting they didn't have to be prompted to talk about the fact that they still very much support ISIS.
It's a very, very strange environment.
There was a very large group of women who were lined up, and it had just been raining, and they were waiting for food.
They had gone for three days in a row to get packages of food, and this was the third day they were being turned away.
So we started talking about the food, and then they started telling me I needed to cover my hair.

And then they started shouting at me convert, convert, and it became this opportunity to ask them about what they believed - every question I've ever had, basically, about what people believe about ISIS.
And they still believe despite everything that the ISIS they lived under, the ISIS that we know was incredibly brutal, was essentially almost like a paradise on Earth.
They felt that everything that happened there was God's will, that no one innocent was killed despite the thousands and thousands of people that ISIS killed.
And they believed the plan was as well that they were sent to the camp - sent there by ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
And one woman tells me that they were sent there because, as she says it, the state is finished, but it will come back.
And she says, you see these and these and these - and she points at the children - these are the next generation of the caliphate.

And indeed, it was some of the children, 11 and 12 year olds, who are some of the most fervent about the blasphemy they saw around them - the music, the tight clothing - and how they prayed for the caliphate to return.
Can you tell how typical the views of these people might be in this camp and some others?
That's a great question.
So there are a lot of people in the camp and a lot of people who did live under ISIS who don't believe in ISIS.
There are quite a few people who feel betrayed by ISIS who realized it wasn't what they thought it was.
But then there are thousands and thousands of people, many of them in this camp, the al-Hol camp, that still believe deeply in ISIS.
And the issue is that they're not being rehabilitated.
They're not being deradicalized in this camp.
They're being denied food, medicine just because there isn't enough of it.
And there are a lot of problems in the camp.
But they all feel that that's deliberate.
And in many cases, it seemed as if their views were hardening rather than softening.
What are some of the proposals about what to do with this large group of people?
How can they be safely resettled?
The government is afraid of the truth.
The government is afraid when the people understand their rights, understand the true meaning of democracy, when the people want to participate, when the people want to set their own destiny.
Well, that is a huge problem.
The Kurdish Syrians who are holding them, the U.S.-backed forces who helped defeat ISIS in its last stronghold in Syria, they're calling for international help.
And they want countries to take back their foreign nationals.
They want Iraq to take back the 30,000-something Iraqis that are in the camp.
But then there are all the others.
There are something like 50 nationalities.
The Americans have taken some back.
Some, they claim, are not really citizens.
There are many Germans.
There are a lot of Russians.
The issue really is the children.
The children are there through no fault of their own.
They're a problem in the camp, and they're a problem if they go home.
So a lot of them are now in limbo.
NPR's Jane Arraf, thanks so much.
Thank you.
